{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2970447,"name":"Zack Inventor","username":"ZBoss","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/z/58f4c7/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-10-04T02:12:41.926Z","cooked":"

Hello, my team is planning on redesigning our 2020 robot. In our new design, we want to use a “rotating drum” serializer similar to team 254, 148, 1684.

From what I understand, the polycarb drum is attached to a lazy susan/turnable on the bottom and there is a belt attached to that turntable… First, is my prediction correct or is there a different solution? Also, where would I buy one of these “large” lazy susan/turnables?

Thank you for any help!

Amazon has some aluminum turntable bearings that are okay. McMaster has some die cast ones that are better. There’s always ways to make this sort of thing yourself if you have the capability.

Right on - the nice thing about McMaster is you’ll get parts with actual ratings (like load and speed for example) and CAD in most cases - helps you to make a good choice for your application beyond just usual sizing concerns.

I believe the 254 spinner was held with classic 1/2" bearings available at all standard FRC vendors.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2021-10-04T02:57:22.741Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":16,"reads":201,"readers_count":200,"score":135.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":396361,"topic_slug":"where-to-buy-lazy-susan-turntable","display_username":"Totally out of touch","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":3609,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/where-to-buy-lazy-susan-turntable/396361/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2970467,"name":"Aiden S","username":"SonofBeans","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sonofbeans/{size}/128230_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-04T03:34:36.749Z","cooked":"

This is the lazy susan we originally used for our hopper, it happens to also be the one the color wheel is set up on. We have since moved to a large bearing, so if I find that link I’ll put that here too. However, I am certain that this would’ve lasted the whole season, just beware that if you let it sit in a hot room for a whole quarantine it will rust over lol. I hope this helps!

EDIT:
I believe this is what we are (or is close to) what we are using now! If you have any other questions, please feel free to ask!

Think about the repercussions.","username":"DonRotolo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/donrotolo/{size}/177200_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-04T15:30:54.189Z","cooked":"

Ours was a large circle cut on the CNC, held in place and guided by V-groove bearings on the chassis.

And we called it Jo-anne, because is wasn’t fair that Susan was always called the lazy one.
